awd_titl_txt: RUI: Bimolecular Collisions in Ionic Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Miroslav Peric and his students at the California State University (CSU) Northridge are studying the collisions between molecules dissolved in room temperature ionic liquids (ILs). ILs are a class of liquids which are being used as environmentally-friendlier substitutes for volatile organic solvents.  The frequency of molecular collisions in a liquid can provide an idea of how quickly chemical reactions can take place in that liquid.  ILs are different from other liquids because they are composed of positively and negatively charged molecules (charged atoms or molecules are called "ions", hence the name ionic liquid).  The current understanding of molecular collisions in IL liquids is limited.  Water, alcohol, and gasoline are common examples of liquids composed of neutral (non-charged) molecules. Professor Peric dissolves "probe" molecules that have magnetic properties into the ILs. He then uses Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy to detect changes in the probe molecule's magnetic properties as the probe collides with the IL.  EPR measures the magnetic properties of electrons in atoms or molecules. A detailed understanding of collision events in ILs, and how these relate to the structure of the ILs may ultimately allow us to design ILs for specific technological applications. The undergraduate and graduate students working on this research project are gaining valuable exposure to a wide range of disciplines, from solution chemistry to physics and quantum mechanics to complex data analysis.

The project is based on the EPR Heisenberg Spin Exchange (HSE) technique that can separate the effects of dipole-dipole and spin exchange interactions in viscous media. This separation enables the measurement of the bimolecular collisions of neutral and charged nitroxides in viscous liquids such as ILs. The translational and rotational diffusion of neutral, singly-charged and doubly-charged nitroxide spin probes in ILs composed of cations and anions of variable sizes is measured as a function of temperature. The choice of the nitroxide spin probes allows for an understanding of the effect of charge on bimolecular collisions of spin probes in ILs. The cations are of a homologous series of substituted imidazoles (ethyl to octyl).  This series of cations allows the Peric team to clarify the role of the hydrophobic part of ILs in solution phase dynamics. Similarly, the anions are of two different sizes (single atom anions and large multi-atom anions) in order to understand the influence of the anion on the translation of solute molecules in ILs. The results are interpreted in terms of the fractional Stokes-Einstein relation and the Cohen-Turnbull free volume equation. The broader impacts of this project include an understanding of transport properties and the kinetics of chemical reactions in ILs, as well as an opportunity for the CSU Northridge students to gain experience in experimental research, cutting-edge instrumentation, and theory, all of which are valuable as the students enter the modern chemical sciences workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI studied the bimolecular collisions between solute molecules dissolved in room-temperature ionic liquids (RTILs), a new class of liquids being explored as green substitutes for volatile organic solvents. RTILs are composed of positively and negatively charged molecules called ions, which gives them their name. The PI used a new spin probe electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) Heisenberg spin exchange (HSE) technique developed in his laboratory to separate the effects of dipole-dipole and spin-exchange interactions on the EPR spectra of paramagnetic molecules in RTILs. This separation allowed him to measure not just the rate of collisions between paramagnetic solute molecules but also their translational diffusion. In addition, the PI could extract the rotational behavior of the same solute molecules. This way, the PI obtained a complete picture of the dynamic behavior of the solute probe molecules in ionic liquids.

 

The Peric team studied the translational diffusion of neutral and charged nitroxide spin probes in RTILs composed of cations and anions of different sizes. They found that the translational motion of charged probes is the same in RTILs regardless of the size of the anion alkyl chain. This result can be explained by the nanostructural organization of the RTILs, consisting of polar and nonpolar nanodomains. Similar translational diffusion rates indicate that the probe?s local environment does not change. Since the nonpolar nanodomain increases with alkyl chain length, the same translational rate suggests that the charged probe diffuses mainly through the polar region. On the other hand, the translational diffusion of the neutral spin probe is faster than that of the charged one and increases with the anion alkyl chain length, indicating that the neutral probe diffuses through the polar and nonpolar domains.

 

The translational diffusion rate of a solute is mainly related to the viscosity and temperature of the solvent, described by the Stokes-Einstein equation. Though the Stokes-Einstein equation describes our translational diffusion results in RTILs well, we showed that the Cohen-Turnbull free-volume theory can also describe the translational diffusion rates in RTILs. Due to the thermodynamic fluctuation, there is an empty changing space between the liquid molecules. Once a void (hole) larger than some critical size appears in the neighborhood of a molecule, the molecule moves into the hole without any energy expense, and it continues hopping through the liquid. In addition, we demonstrated that the Cohen-Turnbull free-volume theory could be used to explain other transport properties such as viscosity, ion self-diffusion, and rotation.

 

The study of the rotational diffusion of neutral, singly-charged, and doubly-charged nitroxide spin probes in RTILs has also given some interesting results. While the rotation of the neutral probe is isotropic, the singly-charged probe rotation is anisotropic. The singly-charged probe rotates about its preferential parallel axis three times faster than the perpendicular axis. The most exciting outcome is the highly anisotropic rotation of doubly-charged nitroxide spin probes in RTILs. While the rotation anisotropy of singly-charged nitroxide does not depend on the length of the alkyl chain, the rotation anisotropy of doubly-charged nitroxide increases with the length of the alkyl chain. The amount of rotational anisotropy indicates the location of each probe. The neutral probe is likely homogeneously distributed throughout the solvent. The singly-charged nitroxide resides in both polar and nonpolar domains but is mainly located in the polar region. The doubly-charged nitroxide probe seems to reside only in the polar domain, especially in the RTILs with longer alkyl chains.

 

In conclusion, the project has advanced understanding of the translational and rotational behavior of neutral, singly-charged, and doubly-charged nitroxide spin probes in RTILs. This understanding can also be applied to the same transport properties of nonmagnetic solute molecules with similar size, shape, and charge. In addition, the project involved four undergraduate and six master's graduate students in research. These students gained valuable experience in high-level research using modern and cutting-edge instrumentation and theory.
